tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem that requires applying the von Mises yield criterion. It involves multiple steps: calculating the von Mises stress, and then calculating the factor of safety. The image is needed to visualize the stress state. It integrates concepts of stress transformation and failure criteria.

answer_validation.reasoning:
For a plane stress state with \(\sigma_{xx}=160\,	ext{MPa}, \sigma_{yy}=40\,	ext{MPa}, 	au_{xy}=80\,	ext{MPa}\), the von Mises equivalent stress is computed using the standard plane-stress form of the von Mises criterion. The 3D von Mises expression is 


\(\sigma_e = \sqrt{	frac{1}{2}\left[(\sigma_1-\sigma_2)^2+(\sigma_2-\sigma_3)^2+(\sigma_3-\sigma_1)^2ight]}\).

For plane stress, an equivalent formula directly in terms of components is 


\(\sigma_e = \sqrt{\sigma_{xx}^2 + \sigma_{yy}^2 - \sigma_{xx}\sigma_{yy} + 3	au_{xy}^2}\).

Substituting the given values: 


\(\sigma_e = \sqrt{160^2 + 40^2 - 160	imes 40 + 3	imes 80^2}\) MPa 

\(= \sqrt{25600 + 1600 - 6400 + 3	imes 6400}\) 

\(= \sqrt{25600 + 1600 - 6400 + 19200}\) 

\(= \sqrt{40000}\) 

\(= 200\,	ext{MPa}.\)

The factor of safety (FoS) is defined as yield stress divided by applied (equivalent) stress: 


\(	ext{FoS} = \dfrac{\sigma_y}{\sigma_e} = \dfrac{250}{200} = 1.25.\)

This matches the official answer range 1.25 to 1.25.

step_by_step: Identify that yielding is governed by the von Mises criterion, so we must compute the von Mises equivalent stress for the given plane stress state.
Write the von Mises equivalent stress formula for plane stress: \(\sigma_e = \sqrt{\sigma_{xx}^2 + \sigma_{yy}^2 - \sigma_{xx}\sigma_{yy} + 3\tau_{xy}^2}\).
Substitute the given stresses: \(\sigma_{xx}=160\,\text{MPa}, \sigma_{yy}=40\,\text{MPa}, \tau_{xy}=80\,\text{MPa}\) and evaluate the expression to get \(\sigma_e = 200\,\text{MPa}\).
Use the definition of factor of safety: \(\text{FoS} = \sigma_y / \sigma_e\), where \(\sigma_y = 250\,\text{MPa}\) is the uniaxial yield stress.
Compute \(\text{FoS} = 250/200 = 1.25\) and round to two decimal places (already exact).

topic.name: Failure theories and yield criteria
topic.syllabus_ref: Solid Mechanics and Structures -> Failure theories (Tresca, von Mises)

essential: Basic stress components in 2D: normal and shear stresses
Von Mises yield criterion for ductile materials
Definition and purpose of factor of safety
helpful: Difference between Tresca and von Mises criteria

Main Concept: requires: knowledge of von Mises equivalent stress formula for plane stress
enables: design of components based on yield criteria under multiaxial loading
enables: comparison of different failure theories (Tresca vs von Mises) in structural design

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling the correct von Mises expression for plane stress
Algebraic mistakes in squaring and adding terms can lead to wrong equivalent stress

textbook_references.author: Beer, Johnston et al.
textbook_references.section: Theories of Failure for Ductile Materials
textbook_references.text_snippet: The distortion-energy (von Mises) theory states that yielding begins when the second deviatoric stress invariant reaches the same value as at yield in simple tension. For plane stress, the equivalent stress is given by \(\sigma_e = (\sigma_x^2 + \sigma_y^2 - \sigma_x\sigma_y + 3\tau_{xy}^2)^{1/2}\).

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.chapter_title: Basic Principles of Stress and Strain
textbook_references.text_snippet: Von Mises yield criterion, also known as the maximum distortion energy theory, is widely used for ductile materials in aircraft structures.

video_references.topic_covered: Von Mises yield criterion and its mathematical form in terms of principal stresses
Tutorial on applying Tresca and von Mises criteria to plane stress problems

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Recognize plane stress \u2192 Use von Mises plane-stress formula \u2192 Compute equivalent stress \u2192 Apply factor of safety definition \u2192 Numerical evaluation
key_insights: For plane stress, von Mises equivalent stress can be written directly in terms of \(\sigma_{xx}, \sigma_{yy}, \tau_{xy}\) without computing principal stresses.
Factor of safety is simply the ratio of material yield strength to this equivalent stress for yield-based design.

formulas_principles.name: Von Mises equivalent stress for plane stress
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula to compute the applied equivalent stress from the given stress components.

formulas_principles.name: General 3D von Mises criterion
formulas_principles.conditions: Uses principal stresses for any 3D stress state.
formulas_principles.relevance: Underlying definition from which the plane-stress form is derived.

formulas_principles.name: Factor of safety based on yield
formulas_principles.conditions: When factor of safety is defined as yield stress divided by applied equivalent stress.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to convert equivalent stress into a safety margin against yielding.

industry_examples: Design of aircraft fuselage skin panels subjected to biaxial tension and shear due to cabin pressurization and aerodynamic loads.
Sizing of thin-walled pressure vessel components where combined membrane and shear stresses occur around cut-outs.
specific_systems: Wing skins and web panels in transport aircraft subjected to combined bending and torsion.
Automotive body panels in crash-critical regions where multiaxial stress states arise.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Engineers must ensure that thin plates and panels in structures do not yield under combined in-plane loads. Using von Mises equivalent stress and an appropriate factor of safety allows safe yet weight-efficient design.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using a simple maximum normal stress (\(\sigma_{max}\)) instead of von Mises equivalent stress to compute factor of safety.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They confuse different failure theories and default to the simplest one they remember.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline the specified failure criterion in the question (von Mises, Tresca, etc.) and recall or write its formula before starting calculations.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an over- or under-estimated factor of safety and an incorrect numerical answer.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting the cross term \(-\sigma_{xx}\sigma_{yy}\) or the factor 3 on \(\tau_{xy}^2\) in the plane-stress von Mises formula.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They try to recall the formula from memory without understanding its derivation.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Memorize the pattern: sum of squares of normals, minus their product, plus three times shear squared. Alternatively, derive quickly from principal stresses if unsure.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives a wrong equivalent stress and thus a wrong factor of safety.

common_mistakes.mistake: Inverting the factor of safety definition and computing \(\sigma_e/\sigma_y\) instead of \(\sigma_y/\sigma_e\).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They mix up design stress vs allowable stress definitions.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: FoS > 1 for safe design; check your result logically. If FoS < 1 under service loads, the design is unsafe.
common_mistakes.consequence: Reports an FoS less than 1 even when stresses are below yield, indicating a misinterpretation.

common_mistakes.mistake: Arithmetic errors when squaring and adding large numbers (e.g., miscomputing 80^2 or 160^2).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing under time pressure and not using a calculator carefully.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Do quick mental checks: 80^2 should be 6400, 160^2 should be 25600; verify intermediate sums before taking the square root.
common_mistakes.consequence: Small arithmetic mistakes can shift the equivalent stress enough to change the final FoS.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: VM plane stress: "Squares SUM, product SUB, shear times 3"
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when recalling the von Mises formula for 2D stress states in exams.

flashcards.front: Write the von Mises equivalent stress formula for a plane stress state with \(\sigma_{xx}, \sigma_{yy}, \tau_{xy}\).
What is the physical meaning of von Mises equivalent stress?
flashcards.back: It is a scalar measure of the distortion energy in a multiaxial stress state. When it reaches the uniaxial yield stress, yielding begins according to the von Mises criterion.

flashcards.front: How is factor of safety (FoS) defined in yield-based design problems like this one?
flashcards.back: FoS is defined as the ratio of yield stress to the applied equivalent stress: \(\text{FoS} = \sigma_y / \sigma_e\).

flashcards.front: A plate has \(\sigma_{xx}=100\,\text{MPa}, \sigma_{yy}=0, \tau_{xy}=0\) and yield stress 250 MPa. What is FoS using von Mises?
If your computed FoS is less than 1 but all stresses are clearly below yield, what should you check?
flashcards.back: Check whether you inverted the FoS definition (used \(\sigma_e/\sigma_y\) instead of \(\sigma_y/\sigma_e\)) and verify your von Mises formula and arithmetic.

real_world_context.application: Design of aircraft skin panels under combined pressurization and aerodynamic loads.
real_world_context.industry_example: A fuselage panel may experience longitudinal and hoop stresses plus shear from torsion. Engineers compute von Mises stress and apply a factor of safety (e.g., 1.25 to 1.5) to ensure no yielding during normal operation.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating equivalent stress or misapplying FoS can lead to local yielding, permanent deformations, and possible fatigue crack initiation in critical structures.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a direct von Mises + FoS plug-in problem. Write the plane-stress formula, substitute numbers carefully, and compute with minimal algebra.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck on the exact formula, you can approximate by computing principal stresses via Mohr's circle and then applying the general von Mises expression, but this takes longer.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2 minutes: 1 minute to recall/write formula and 1 minute for substitution and calculator work.

search_keywords: von Mises yield criterion plane stress
equivalent stress formula sigma_x sigma_y tau_xy
GATE AE strength of materials failure theories
factor of safety based on yielding
principal stresses and Mohr circle tutorial

alternative_methods.name: Principal Stress Method
alternative_methods.description: First compute the in-plane principal stresses using Mohr\'s circle or transformation equations, then apply the general von Mises formula in terms of \(\sigma_1, \sigma_2, \sigma_3\) (with \(\sigma_3=0\) for plane stress).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Reinforces understanding of principal stresses and works even if you forget the plane-stress shortcut. Cons: More algebra and time-consuming; easier to make arithmetic errors.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Use when you remember the general von Mises expression but not the compact plane-stress form.

connections_to_other_subjects.Solid Mechanics: Uses stress transformation, principal stresses, and failure theories covered in basic strength of materials.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aircraft Structures: Von Mises criterion is central to sizing thin-walled aircraft components under combined loading.
connections_to_other_subjects.Finite Element Analysis: FEA post-processing often reports von Mises stress contours for complex structures to assess yielding.
connections_to_other_subjects.Materials Science: Connects to plasticity theory and the role of shear (distortion) energy in yielding of ductile metals.

deeper_dive_topics: Derivation of von Mises criterion from distortion energy and stress invariants
Comparison of yield surfaces in principal stress space for Tresca and von Mises
Extension of yield criteria to anisotropic materials and composite laminates
Elastic-plastic analysis and safety factors in limit state design

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Stress and strain; failure theories for ductile materials
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent representative question for applying von Mises criterion and factor of safety in a simple plane stress scenario.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided detailed explanations of von Mises criterion, its formula in terms of principal stresses, and its application to torsion and plane stress examples, as well as factor of safety usage. Although the exact plane-stress component form was not explicitly given, it is standard and was supplied from internal knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Ask for factor of safety using Tresca criterion for the same stress state and compare with von Mises.
Modify the problem to include a non-zero \(\sigma_{zz}\) and require use of the full 3D von Mises expression.
Ask students to compute principal stresses first, then apply von Mises, to test understanding of both steps.
Extend to a design question: determine the maximum allowable \(\tau_{xy}\) for a specified factor of safety.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text:
A thin flat plate is subjected to the following stresses:
$\sigma_{xx} = 160$ MPa; $\sigma_{yy} = 40$ MPa; $\tau_{xy} = 80$ MPa.
Factor of safety is defined as the ratio of the yield stress to the applied stress. The yield stress of the material under uniaxial tensile load is 250 MPa. The factor of safety for the plate assuming that material failure is governed by the von Mises criterion is _____ (rounded off to two decimal places).
